questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet.

questions.question: Foundation brakes are used:
questions.answerB: Only at the rear wheels.
questions.answerC: Only at the driver’s side wheels.
questions.answerD: At each wheel.
questions.explanation: Foundation brakes are used at each wheel. The most common type is the S-cam drum brake.

questions.question: A driver can have:
questions.answerA: Two licenses, one for automobiles and one for trucks.
questions.answerB: Only one license.
questions.answerC: A license for each state in which they plan to drive.
questions.answerD: An automobile license from one state and a CDL from another.
questions.explanation: A person cannot have more than one license. States share driver data through a computer database to prevent the issuance of duplicate licenses.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is best to always accelerate very slowly.
questions.answerB: So they do not lose control of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: So the driver does not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerD: To be the last vehicle through an intersection.
questions.explanation: Speeding up too quickly on a road with poor traction could cause a driver to lose control of their vehicle. In conditions that cause poor traction, a driver should accelerate especially smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: When doing an inspection, ensure that the brake pads are:
questions.answerB: Covered with coolant.
questions.answerC: Covered with oil.
questions.answerD: Free of oil or grease.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle's brakes, you should make sure the shoes and pads do not have oil, grease, or brake fluid on them.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a backing maneuver that you will be asked to perform during the basic control skills test?
questions.answerB: Offset back/right
questions.answerC: Offset back/left
questions.answerD: Blind offset
questions.explanation: Backing maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right, offset back/left, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is:
questions.answerB: 6 psi in one minute.
questions.answerC: 8 psi in one minute.
questions.answerD: 4 psi in one minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: What does ABS do?
questions.answerB: Prevent the air compressor from overheating
questions.answerC: Prevent the front brakes from being used on ice
questions.answerD: Prevent the brakes from being used if downshifting would be more effective
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheels from locking up during hard applications of the brakes, especially on slippery surfaces.

questions.question: Roads are slippery when it first begins to rain because:
questions.answerB: The fresh rain mixes with oil on the roadway.
questions.answerC: The water has nowhere to go.
questions.answerD: Concrete can be slippery.
questions.explanation: Roads are especially slippery when it first begins to rain. Rain water initially mixes with oil and grease on the road to form a slippery film. As the rain continues, this mixture will eventually wash away.

questions.question: Failing to exit your vehicle properly during an exercise in the basic vehicle control skills test will result in:
questions.answerB: A reset of that exercise.
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.answerD: An extra point against your score.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: To help your vehicle be seen by others:
questions.answerB: Headlights should be turned off during the day.
questions.answerC: Headlights should be covered with grease.
questions.answerD: Headlights should only be used in the rain.
questions.explanation: When driving at night, it is important that your lights be clean so that they provide as much light as possible. This will help others to see your vehicle.

questions.question: If another driver is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Increase the space in front of your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Flash your lights.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is advisable to open up the space in front of your vehicle, making it easier for the tailgater to get around you. Speeding up may be counterproductive because the driver may continue to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: When checking the engine compartment, you should check all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The coolant level in the radiator.
questions.answerC: The windshield washer fluid level.
questions.answerD: The fuel level.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine compartment, be sure to check the oil level; the radiator coolant level and the condition of the hoses; the power steering fluid level and the condition of the hoses, if applicable; the windshield washer fluid level; the battery connections, fluid level, and tie-downs; the automatic transmission fluid level; and the condition and tightness of the belts. Additionally, check for any leaks in the engine compartment and cracked or worn electrical wiring insulation.

questions.question: During exercises that are not the straight line backing exercise, you may exit your vehicle to check its position no more than:
questions.answerB: Two times.
questions.answerC: Three times.
questions.answerD: Four times.
questions.explanation: A driver is allowed to exit their vehicle to check its position during any basic control skills test exercise. This action is called a "look." During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when:
questions.answerB: Air pressure falls below 20 psi.
questions.answerC: Driving downhill.
questions.answerD: Driving uphill.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure drops to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes is ____ in a minute.
questions.answerB: 5 psi
questions.answerC: 7 psi
questions.answerD: 9 psi
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: When using mirrors while driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Look in the mirrors for extended periods of time.
questions.answerC: Use only the rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: Use only the driver’s side mirror.
questions.explanation: Focusing on your mirrors for too long can be dangerous because you will have traveled a substantial distance without looking at the road ahead.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: You should move your vehicle quickly.
questions.answerB: You should move your vehicle slowly.
questions.answerC: The move should be made with a jerking motion.
questions.answerD: You do not need to use a turn signal.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly to maintain control of your vehicle. Doing this will also allow a driver that you did not see time to move out of the way of your vehicle. Use the proper turn signal to communicate with other road users.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal should activate:
questions.answerA: When tank pressure falls below 120 psi.
questions.answerB: When tank pressure falls below 60 psi.
questions.answerC: When tank pressure falls below 10 psi.
questions.answerD: When tank pressure falls below 5 psi.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low air pressure warning signal must come on if air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi. This warning signal may come in the form of a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: When driving:
questions.answerA: It is best to hide your intentions from others.
questions.answerB: You should only use turn signals if there are vehicles near you.
questions.answerC: You should not use turn signals in construction zones.
questions.answerD: You should always use turn signals to warn others about your intentions.
questions.explanation: It is important to communicate your intentions to others on the road. Make sure to signal before turning or changing lanes, even if no other vehicles are nearby.

questions.question: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is:
questions.answerB: To maximize gas mileage.
questions.answerC: To wake up before the drive.
questions.answerD: To fill up time.
questions.explanation: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is to ensure the safety of yourself and others on the road. Safety inspections before every trip are required by state and federal laws.

questions.question: How can you avoid becoming drowsy on a trip?
questions.answerA: Get about three hours of sleep beforehand.
questions.answerB: Plan ahead, including stopping points.
questions.answerC: Do not build exercise into your daily routine.
questions.answerD: Schedule the trip at night.
questions.explanation: Strategies to reduce the risk of fatigue while driving include getting seven to eight hours of sleep beforehand; scheduling trips for the hours during which you are normally awake; planning to take breaks during the trip; and exercising regularly.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you will need to identify all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The water pump belt.
questions.answerC: The alternator belt.
questions.answerD: The water compressor belt.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must check the power steering belt, water pump belt, alternator belt, and air compressor belt for snugness, cracks, or frays. If any of these components are not belt-driven, you must tell the examiner which one(s), and verify that they are operating properly, mounted securely, and not damaged or leaking.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is:
questions.answerB: 8 psi in a minute.
questions.answerC: 6 psi in a minute.
questions.answerD: 4 psi in a minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: You should cover cargo:
questions.answerA: To protect the cargo from thieves.
questions.answerB: To protect the cargo from weather.
questions.answerC: To prevent other drivers from looking at what is being transported.
questions.answerD: To keep the cargo a secret.
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: When driving with a load, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Stop and check on the cargo within the first 50 miles of the trip.
questions.answerB: Ask other drivers about the condition of their load.
questions.answerC: Use the side mirrors only to check on the cargo.
questions.answerD: Not check on the cargo if it was secured properly before starting the trip.
questions.explanation: Cargo and its securing devices must be inspected before starting a trip. After beginning a trip, the driver should check the load and securing devices within the first 50 miles on the road, every three hours or 150 miles traveled, and after every break.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using flashing lights so other road users move out of your path.
questions.answerC: Drive at a safe speed and arrive when you arrive.
questions.answerD: Get upset.
questions.explanation: To avoid engaging in dangerous and aggressive driving behavior, you should relax and accept any delays that arise throughout a trip. To help avoid the stress of arriving late to a destination, plan for likely delays when planning your drive.

questions.question: Sometimes, when checking the automatic transmission fluid level:
questions.answerA: Your vehicle should be parked uphill.
questions.answerB: Your vehicle should be parked downhill.
questions.answerC: Your vehicle should be washed.
questions.answerD: Your vehicle may have to be left running.
questions.explanation: In some vehicles, you may have to leave the engine running to check the automatic transmission fluid level.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection includes ____ basic steps.
questions.answerB: Four
questions.answerC: Seven
questions.answerD: Nine
questions.explanation: There are seven basic steps to a pre-trip inspection. These steps include completing an overview of the vehicle; checking the engine compartment; starting the engine and inspecting inside the cab; turning off the engine and checking the lights; a walk-around inspection; checking the signal lights; and starting the engine and checking the brakes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of a person being drowsy?
questions.answerB: Drifting from your lane
questions.answerC: Feeling hungry
questions.answerD: Yawning
questions.explanation: Driving drowsy is dangerous and should always be avoided. Warning signs of drowsiness include frequent blinking, your eyes closing or going out of focus by themselves, frequent yawning, and drifting between lanes.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.answerB: 8 psi in a minute.
questions.answerC: 6 psi in a minute.
questions.answerD: 4 psi in a minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A double combination vehicle should have a leakage rate no higher than 4 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: In general, if you are convicted of a traffic violation in your personal car:
questions.answerA: The convicting officer will alert your employer.
questions.answerB: Your CDL will not be affected because the violation is on your personal license.
questions.answerC: You should tell your employer within six months.
questions.answerD: You must tell your employer within 30 days.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: When other vehicles have trouble seeing you at dawn or dusk, you can increase your visibility by:
questions.answerB: Honking your horn.
questions.answerC: Turning on your headlights.
questions.answerD: Turning on your windshield wipers.
questions.explanation: At dawn or dusk, and in snowy or rainy conditions, you should turn on your headlights to make it easier for other road users to see your vehicle.

questions.question: Failing to drain the tanks in an air brake system can result in:
questions.answerA: Water freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.answerB: Squishy brakes.
questions.answerC: Too much air collecting.
questions.answerD: Too much fuel being carried.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do this can cause damage. For example, water that has built up in the system could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: When driving, the steering wheel should be:
questions.answerB: Held with both hands on opposite sides of the wheel.
questions.answerC: Held with both hands at the bottom of the wheel.
questions.answerD: Held with both hands at the top of the wheel.
questions.explanation: Hold the steering wheel firmly with both hands, placing them on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: The service brake system:
questions.answerA: Applies and releases the brakes when you press the brake pedal while driving normally.
questions.answerB: Applies and releases the parking brakes.
questions.answerC: Applies and releases the emergency brake.
questions.answerD: Applies and releases the axle brake.
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system. The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when you use the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: When driving through fog, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Use low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Run the windshield wipers.
questions.answerD: Drive on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in fog, you should use your low beam headlights.

questions.question: Which of the following is not another name for convex mirrors?
questions.answerB: Spot mirrors
questions.answerC: Bug-eye mirrors
questions.answerD: Flat side mirrors
questions.explanation: Convex mirrors are also known as "fisheye", "spot", or "bug-eye" mirrors.

questions.question: If driving a truck that requires a CDL for operation:
questions.answerA: You do not need to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if transporting more than 500 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerC: You are always required to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerD: You are only required to wear a seat belt when driving a tank trailer.
questions.explanation: For safety, you must wear your seat belt at all times while operating a CMV.

questions.question: The brake pedal is part of which braking system?
questions.answerB: The parking brake system
questions.answerC: The emergency brake system
questions.answerD: The auxiliary brake system
questions.explanation: The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when a driver presses the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: What is another name for front-end header boards?
questions.answerB: Cargo stoppers
questions.answerC: Head braces
questions.answerD: Ballasts
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect the driver from cargo moving in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: The steering wheel should be:
questions.answerB: Held by one hand to allow for other tasks, such as eating and drinking.
questions.answerC: Held by one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.answerD: Cracked to allow for an improved grip.
questions.explanation: To maintain proper control of your vehicle, the steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands. Your hands should be positioned on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: When driving at highway speeds, you should watch the road about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: 100 yards
questions.answerC: One quarter mile
questions.answerD: One mile
questions.explanation: Stay aware of upcoming obstacles and hazards by consistently watching the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of your vehicle. When traveling at highway speeds, this is equivalent to about a quarter of a mile.

questions.question: The front of an enclosed trailer should:
questions.answerB: Contain rags.
questions.answerC: Not be used for cargo.
questions.answerD: Be free of cracks.
questions.explanation: When inspecting an enclosed trailer as a part of the vehicle inspection test, check the front area of the trailer for signs of damage, such as cracks, bulges, or holes.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you will be evaluated on your lane usage. Which of the following is an example of poor lane usage?
questions.answerA: Not driving over curbs or sidewalks
questions.answerB: Stopping behind crosswalks
questions.answerC: Driving in the leftmost lane if more than one driving lane is available
questions.answerD: Finishing a right turn in the rightmost lane
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, make sure you do not put your vehicle over curbs, sidewalks, or lane markings. Stop behind stop lines, crosswalks, or stop signs. On multiple-lane roads, complete turns in the proper lane. Always move to or remain in the rightmost lane, unless the lane is blocked.

questions.question: Once stopped as a part of the stop/start maneuver, you should:
questions.answerB: Not use the four-way flashers because it is just a test, not an emergency.
questions.answerC: Leave the vehicle in first gear.
questions.answerD: Park in front of a fire hydrant.
questions.explanation: Once you have stopped as a part of the stop/start maneuver during the on-road driving skills test, you must activate your four-way flashers and shift into neutral or park. You must not block any driveways, intersections, fire hydrants, or signs.

questions.question: When checking the air and electrical lines during a vehicle inspection, all of the following should be true, except:
questions.answerA: The air hoses are making a hissing noise.
questions.answerB: The air hoses and electrical lines are not cut.
questions.answerC: The air lines are not pinched.
questions.answerD: The air lines are not dragging against tractor parts.
questions.explanation: When examining the air and electrical lines as part of your vehicle inspection test, you must listen for leaks. Ensure that the air hoses and electrical lines are not cut, chafed, spliced, or worn. Make sure air and electrical lines are not tangled, pinched, or dragging against tractor parts.

questions.question: If a school bus needs to be evacuated, passengers should:
questions.answerB: Always use the windows.
questions.answerC: Always use the front door.
questions.answerD: Use the exit deemed safest.
questions.explanation: If a school bus needs to be evacuated in the event of an emergency, the driver must quickly determine which exit or exits will be safest for students to use and direct the students to that exit.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be required to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Point to or touch each item.
questions.answerC: Explain what you are checking and why.
questions.answerD: Crawl under the vehicle.
questions.explanation: As a part of earning your CDL, you will have to pass an inspection test and demonstrate that your vehicle is safe for operation. During the vehicle inspection test, you will have to walk around the vehicle and point to or touch each item and explain to the examiner what you are checking and why. You will not have to crawl under the hood or under the vehicle.

questions.question: In the event of a bus evacuation, students should be led at least ____ away from the road.
questions.answerB: 20 feet
questions.answerC: 50 feet
questions.answerD: 100 feet
questions.explanation: If it is necessary to evacuate a school bus, students should be led by the driver in the direction of oncoming traffic to a safe location that is at least 100 feet off the road. This will help to ensure that they are not hit by flying debris if another vehicle hits the bus.

questions.question: A blind spot extends at least ____ behind a school bus.
questions.answerB: 50 feet
questions.answerC: 100 feet
questions.answerD: 1,000 feet
questions.explanation: A school bus has blind spots immediately below the side flat mirrors, immediately in front of the side flat mirrors, and directly behind the rear bumper. Rear blind spots typically extend 50 to 150 feet behind a bus but can sometimes extend up to 400 feet, depending on the length of the vehicle.

questions.question: When alley docking, your vehicle should be parked:
questions.answerA: With the front bumper on top of the front boundary line.
questions.answerB: With the rear wheels over the rear boundary line.
questions.answerC: Straight within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.answerD: At an angle within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: Which of the following is not acceptable emergency equipment?
questions.answerB: Six fuses
questions.answerC: Three liquid burning flares
questions.answerD: Four yellow squares
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will need to show emergency equipment, including spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and a properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: What do outside crossover mirrors allow a driver to see?
questions.answerB: The rear bumper
questions.answerC: The right side of the bus
questions.answerD: The left side of the bus
questions.explanation: Crossover mirrors are used to help a school bus driver see the danger zone area directly in front of the bus, as well as the danger zone areas to the left and right sides of the bus, including the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: During the skills test, if making a turn that requires a stop, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop after the stop line to get a better view.
questions.answerC: Allow your vehicle to roll.
questions.answerD: Keep the front wheels aimed straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If you must come to a stop before making a turn during the driving skills test, you should come to a smooth stop behind any stop line, crosswalk, or stop sign. Keep your front wheels aimed straight ahead and do not let your vehicle roll. If stopping behind another vehicle, stop where you are still able to see the rear tires of the vehicle ahead of you.

questions.question: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Check traffic thoroughly in all directions.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed before entering the curve.
questions.answerC: Keep your vehicle in its lane.
questions.answerD: Steadily use the brakes throughout the curve.
questions.explanation: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you should thoroughly check traffic in all directions. Before entering the curve, reduce your speed sufficiently so that further braking or shifting is not required. Keep your vehicle in its lane and continue checking traffic in all directions.

questions.question: After traveling under an overpass during the driving skills test, you may be asked to recall:
questions.answerB: The posted weight limit.
questions.answerC: The width of the opening.
questions.answerD: If there was a shoulder near the roadway.
questions.explanation: If you drive under an overpass during the on-road driving skills test, your examiner may ask you to recall the posted clearance or height of the overpass.

questions.question: If driving a school bus, your four-way flashers should:
questions.answerA: Be activated before crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerB: Never be used.
questions.answerC: Only be used after crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerD: Only be used near railroad tracks if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: When driving a school bus, you must activate your four-way flashers while approaching and crossing a railroad crossing. Deactivate the flashers once your entire vehicle has cleared the tracks.

questions.question: If a student drops an item near a stopped bus, they should:
questions.answerA: Hurry and pick up the item.
questions.answerB: Leave the item behind.
questions.answerC: Ask the driver to pick up the object.
questions.answerD: Have another student pick it up.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous for students to retrieve dropped items because doing so could cause them to disappear from the driver's view at a crucial moment. If an item is dropped, the student should get out of the bus's danger zones, get the attention of the driver, and ask the driver to retrieve the item.

questions.question: The loading of a school bus:
questions.answerB: Does not need to be supervised.
questions.answerC: Should be done quickly.
questions.answerD: Can be dangerous.
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year during loading or unloading of school buses than while riding on school buses. Therefore, it is critical that school bus drivers follow appropriate safety procedures during loading and unloading.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a backing maneuver that you will be asked to perform during the basic control skills test?
questions.answerB: Offset back/right
questions.answerC: Offset back/left
questions.answerD: Blind offset
questions.explanation: Backing maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right, offset back/left, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: When exiting your vehicle, you:
questions.answerA: Must maintain four points of contact with the vehicle.
questions.answerB: May turn to face the road before your exit is complete.
questions.answerC: Must be facing away from the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Must be facing the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Obey all traffic laws.
questions.answerC: Complete the test without a moving violation.
questions.answerD: Obey all traffic signs and signals, but only if other traffic is present.
questions.explanation: You must drive in a safe and responsible manner during the on-road driving test. This includes wearing your safety belt; obeying all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and completing the test without an accident or moving violation.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerA: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.answerB: Drive in a figure eight.
questions.answerC: Alley dock.
questions.answerD: Sound your horn.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: When asked to make a lane change during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerA: Make the necessary traffic checks first.
questions.answerB: Not use your mirrors.
questions.answerC: Cut off other vehicles if needed to follow the instructions.
questions.answerD: Not make the lane change if you don’t want to.
questions.explanation: You will be asked to make multiple lane changes during the driving skills test. Before changing lanes, you should make the necessary traffic checks and use proper signals. Change lanes smoothly when you can do so safely.

questions.question: A blind spot extends at least ____ behind a school bus.
questions.answerB: 50 feet
questions.answerC: 100 feet
questions.answerD: 1,000 feet
questions.explanation: A school bus has blind spots immediately below the side flat mirrors, immediately in front of the side flat mirrors, and directly behind the rear bumper. Rear blind spots typically extend 50 to 150 feet behind a bus but can sometimes extend up to 400 feet, depending on the length of the vehicle.

questions.question: If you miss a student’s stop while bringing students home after school, you should:
questions.answerB: Follow locally established procedures.
questions.answerC: Not worry about the student.
questions.answerD: Stop quickly and let them exit.
questions.explanation: If a school bus driver forgets to stop where a student is meant to unload, the driver should not back up to the stop. Instead, they should follow established local procedures.

questions.question: A school bus must be evacuated if:
questions.answerA: The bus has stalled in winter weather conditions.
questions.answerB: The air conditioning system has broken.
questions.answerC: There is any imminent danger of collision.
questions.answerD: Students are getting motion sickness.
questions.explanation: During emergency situations, it is usually safest for students to remain on a school bus. Evacuations are mandatory if the bus has stalled on railroad tracks, if the bus is on fire or there is a threat of fire, or if there is a hazardous materials spill. Students should be evacuated any time there is imminent danger of collision.

questions.question: A school bus stop:
questions.answerA: Can be added by the driver if there is a need.
questions.answerB: Should be voted on by the students.
questions.answerC: May change, depending on weather conditions.
questions.answerD: Should be established by the proper school district authorities.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should not alter the location of a bus stop without written authorization of the appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: If a school bus needs to be evacuated, passengers should:
questions.answerB: Always use the windows.
questions.answerC: Always use the front door.
questions.answerD: Use the exit deemed safest.
questions.explanation: If a school bus needs to be evacuated in the event of an emergency, the driver must quickly determine which exit or exits will be safest for students to use and direct the students to that exit.

questions.question: If equipped, a header board should:
questions.answerB: Be loose.
questions.answerC: Be strong enough to contain cargo.
questions.answerD: Light up when the engine is started.
questions.explanation: When checking a header board during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that it is secure, free of damage, and strong enough to contain cargo.

questions.question: When exiting your vehicle, you:
questions.answerA: Must maintain four points of contact with the vehicle.
questions.answerB: May turn to face the road before your exit is complete.
questions.answerC: Must be facing away from the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Must be facing the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: The area to the left of a school bus is considered especially dangerous to students because:
questions.answerA: The sun’s reflection obscures the left side of the bus.
questions.answerB: Passing vehicles are located to the left of the bus.
questions.answerC: It is difficult to see the left side of any bus.
questions.answerD: There is no door on the left side of the bus.
questions.explanation: While all sides of a school bus have danger zones, the left side is particularly hazardous to students due to the presence of passing vehicles.

questions.question: When asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.answerB: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull forward to the right, then back in a straight line.
questions.answerD: Pull forward to the left, then back in a straight line.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the left. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: After driving over a bridge during the driving skills test, you may be asked to recall.
questions.answerB: The color of a sign you just passed.
questions.answerC: How many lanes of traffic there were on the bridge.
questions.answerD: If there was a crosswalk on the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you drive over a bridge during the on-road driving skills test, the examiner may ask you afterwards to recall the bridge's posted weight limit.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that lug nuts are all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Free of distortions.
questions.answerC: Loose.
questions.answerD: Free of rust.
questions.explanation: During a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that all lug nuts are present, free of cracks and distortions, and showing no signs of looseness, such as rust trails or shiny threads. Verify that all bolt holes are free of cracks and distortions.

questions.question: If equipped with flashing lights, how far in advance of a school bus stop should the bus's lights be activated?
questions.answerB: At least 100 feet
questions.answerC: At least 200 feet
questions.answerD: At least 1,000 feet
questions.explanation: If a school bus is equipped with alternating flashing amber warning lights, they should be activated at least 200 feet before a stop, unless state law requires otherwise.

questions.question: When you are approaching a bus stop, the students on your bus should:
questions.answerB: Stand up and collect their belongings.
questions.answerC: Walk to the front of the bus and prepare to exit.
questions.answerD: Ask the driver questions.
questions.explanation: Students on a school bus should remain seated until they are told otherwise. It is unsafe for students to walk around the bus while it is moving.

questions.question: During the basic control skills test, you can acquire points by:
questions.answerB: Pulling up one time.
questions.answerC: Exiting the vehicle one time to check your positioning.
questions.answerD: Setting the parking brake.
questions.explanation: The examiner will score the number of times your vehicle touches or crosses an exercise boundary line. Each encroachment will count as an error, resulting in points against your skills test score.

questions.question: Drivers should try to stop ____ away from students at a bus stop.
questions.answerB: At least 50 feet
questions.answerC: At least 10 feet
questions.answerD: Less than 10 feet
questions.explanation: A school bus should stop at least 10 feet away from students who are being picked up at a bus stop. This forces the students to walk toward the bus, allowing the driver to observe their movements and better monitor their locations.

questions.question: When asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.answerB: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull forward to the right, then back in a straight line.
questions.answerD: Pull forward to the left, then back in a straight line.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, be sure that:
questions.answerA: The emergency exits are difficult to open.
questions.answerB: The emergency exit warning devices work properly.
questions.answerC: The emergency exits squeak.
questions.answerD: The emergency exits are not accessible from inside the cab.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that any emergency exit warning devices are working. All emergency exits should operate smoothly, be undamaged, and close securely from the inside.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving skills test, you will be evaluated on your gear usage. You should not:
questions.answerB: Select a gear that does not rev the engine.
questions.answerC: Forget to shift through an intersection.
questions.answerD: Shift while taking a turn.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you will be evaluated on your gear usage. Select a gear that does not rev or lug the engine; avoid grinding and clashing gears; and avoid shifting through turns or intersections.

questions.question: A person working on a disabled vehicle on the shoulder of a road:
questions.answerA: Will likely pay attention to traffic on the road.
questions.answerB: May be focused on the repair and not paying attention to roadway traffic.
questions.answerC: Is exempt from traffic laws.
questions.answerD: Should not be assisted.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on disabled vehicles. The task will likely consume their attention, so they may not be aware of traffic or other hazards on the road.

questions.question: During a trip, which shut-off valves should be open?
questions.answerA: All shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerB: The rear shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerC: All shut-off valves should be in the open position, except the rear shut-off valves.
questions.answerD: No shut-off valves should be open.
questions.explanation: When starting a trip, be sure that all shut-off valves are in the open position, except for the last valves on the rear trailer. It is important that air reaches the brakes on all trailers and that the air is not able to escape from the back of the vehicle.

questions.question: When coupling a trailer:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple matching glad hands.
questions.answerB: Any glad hand can be connected to any other glad hand.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand unattached.
questions.answerD: Only one set of glad hands should be connected.
questions.explanation: When coupling, make sure you couple matching glad hands. They are often color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: A pre-trip vehicle inspection:
questions.answerA: Is not required if the driver regularly uses the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Is not required for trips under 100 miles.
questions.answerC: Is only to be performed by a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Is required by law.
questions.explanation: Drivers are required by state and federal law to inspect their vehicles before beginning to drive.

questions.question: Hazardous materials may be transported:
questions.answerA: By any driver with a CDL.
questions.answerB: By any driver, as long as the total weight of the hazardous materials are under 50 pounds.
questions.answerC: By any driver in a rural area.
questions.answerD: By a driver with a CDL and HazMat endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: HazMat endorsement holders must be fingerprinted:
questions.answerB: Every time the endorsement is renewed.
questions.answerC: Only once.
questions.answerD: Before transporting each HazMat load.
questions.explanation: When applying for or renewing a HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a Federal Security Threat Assessment, which includes being fingerprinted.

questions.question: A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause:
questions.answerB: The tractor protection valve to open.
questions.answerC: The rear trailer to detach from the combination.
questions.answerD: The emergency brakes to activate.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line controls the emergency brakes on a combination vehicle. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.answerA: Any risks of fire or explosion.
questions.answerB: Value of the materials.
questions.answerC: Driver information.
questions.answerD: How many people should respond in the event of an accident.
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: If you are driving so slowly that you could impede other vehicles, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive with your emergency flashers activated.
questions.answerC: Not use any lights.
questions.answerD: Wave an arm out of your window.
questions.explanation: If you must drive slowly, you should use your emergency flashers to warn other drivers. Be sure that the use of emergency flashers is permitted by local laws.

questions.question: What can change the height of a vehicle?
questions.answerB: Length
questions.answerC: Weight
questions.answerD: Number of windows
questions.explanation: The added weight of a heavy load will make a vehicle sit lower than usual. A vehicle will often be taller when carrying a light load than when carrying a heavy load. If your vehicle fits under an overpass while carrying a full load, it is not guaranteed that it will fit under the same overpass if it is empty.

questions.question: Areas of the road that are shaded:
questions.answerB: Usually do not contain moisture, so they can’t freeze.
questions.answerC: Will remain slick after ice on other areas of the road has melted.
questions.answerD: Should always be avoided.
questions.explanation: Because they are exposed to less sunlight, shaded patches of road will stay cooler longer than other areas of the road. Due to the lack of direct sunlight, shady areas can remain icy and slippery after ice on other areas of the road has melted.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerB: Increases your braking distance.
questions.answerC: Creates a loud squeaking noise when being used.
questions.answerD: Helps to ensure control while braking.
questions.explanation: ABS increases a driver's control during braking. It will not necessarily change the distance needed for a vehicle to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly before other vehicles get into the lane you wish to occupy.
questions.answerB: Move slowly, in case another vehicle is in the lane you wish to occupy.
questions.answerC: Not use your turn signal.
questions.answerD: Never use the right lane.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly. If you did not see drivers who are already using the lane you wish to occupy, this will give them a chance to get out of your way or honk their horns to alert you. Always signal before changing lanes.

questions.question: How many daily hours of sleep does an adult need to maintain alertness?
questions.answerB: Seven to eight
questions.answerC: Eight to nine
questions.answerD: Four to five
questions.explanation: Being properly rested is essential to the safe operation of a CMV. To maintain alertness, most people need eight to nine hours of sleep per night.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a shipping paper?
questions.answerB: Bills of lading
questions.answerC: Manifests
questions.answerD: Directions
questions.explanation: A shipping paper describes hazardous materials being transported. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all shipping papers.

questions.question: What is the number one cause of death and injury in work zones?
questions.answerB: Careless behavior by construction workers
questions.answerC: Drivers driving too slowly
questions.answerD: Equipment placed in the roadway
questions.explanation: Speeding traffic is the main cause of death and injury in work zones. Drive with special caution when traveling near road workers.

questions.question: After the engine is started, warning lights and buzzers should all:
questions.answerB: Flicker occasionally.
questions.answerC: Turn off right away.
questions.answerD: Turn off once the vehicle begins moving.
questions.explanation: After the engine is started, the warning lights and buzzers should deactivate immediately. The charging circuit warning, oil, coolant, and Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) lights should all turn off.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerB: There is no trailer attached to the tractor.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.answerD: The vehicle is on a slight decline.
questions.explanation: If a trailer is attached to a tractor, the adjustment of the vehicle's mirrors can only be checked accurately if the trailer is straight.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely to result in hydroplaning?
questions.answerB: Using properly inflated tires
questions.answerC: Using new tires
questions.answerD: Traveling at speeds under 10 mph
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is most likely to occur on wet roads if tire pressure is low or if tire tread is worn. If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: Hazardous materials laws are controlled by:
questions.answerB: State regulations.
questions.answerC: Federal regulations.
questions.answerD: All levels of government.
questions.explanation: Because of the risks presented by the nature of the materials, government on federal, state, and local levels may impose regulations on the transportation of hazardous materials.

questions.question: If you must make a quick stop while transporting liquids, one safe option is to:
questions.answerB: Turn while braking.
questions.answerC: Apply the parking brake.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes with minimal pressure.
questions.explanation: A tank vehicle transporting liquids is less stable than other vehicles and may be prone to roll over or skid if not operated in a safe manner. If you must make a quick stop to avoid an accident while transporting liquid cargo, it safest to use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method.

questions.question: Accelerating roughly is:
questions.answerB: Encouraged at all speeds.
questions.answerC: Discouraged, as it may cause damage to the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Discouraged, as it may confuse other drivers.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: When loading or unloading explosive materials, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn off the engine.
questions.answerC: Use sharp-pointed tools to open the packages.
questions.answerD: Toss packages.
questions.explanation: Always turn off your vehicle's engine before loading or unloading explosive materials. Never drop, throw, or roll packages containing explosives.

questions.question: When backing a trailer, how should you turn the steering wheel?
questions.answerA: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerB: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerC: It doesn’t matter.
questions.answerD: It depends on where the trailer is being backed.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once the trailer begins turning, you should then switch the direction of the steering wheel to follow the trailer.

questions.question: If driving a vehicle with a manual transmission, you can prevent your vehicle from rolling backward when starting from a stop by:
questions.answerA: Partly engaging the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Placing the vehicle in reverse before moving forward.
questions.answerC: Fully engaging the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Placing the vehicle in neutral before moving forward.
questions.explanation: To prevent rolling backward when starting from a stop, you should partly engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake. Apply the parking brake whenever necessary to prevent your vehicle from rolling back.

questions.question: The service air line is attached to the:
questions.answerB: Supply line.
questions.answerC: Emergency air line.
questions.answerD: Steering wheel.
questions.explanation: The service air line carries air and is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is attached to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied quickly.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of a person being drowsy?
questions.answerB: Drifting from your lane
questions.answerC: Feeling hungry
questions.answerD: Yawning
questions.explanation: Driving drowsy is dangerous and should always be avoided. Warning signs of drowsiness include frequent blinking, your eyes closing or going out of focus by themselves, frequent yawning, and drifting between lanes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a rule for using turn signals?
questions.answerB: Signal continuously.
questions.answerC: Cancel your signal once your turn or lane change is complete.
questions.answerD: Don’t signal unless another vehicle is close.
questions.explanation: Always signal before a turn or lane change. Begin signaling well in advance of the movement and keep the signal on continuously during the turn. If it is not self-canceling, make sure to turn your signal off after your turn or lane change is complete.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.answerC: Made of cardboard.
questions.answerD: A maximum of four feet tall.
questions.explanation: Containers of hazardous materials must be braced so that they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation.

questions.question: How could you reduce your stress while driving?
questions.answerB: Talk on your cell phone
questions.answerC: Gesture at other drivers
questions.answerD: Listen to calming music
questions.explanation: Being under stress can lead to aggressive driving, which is dangerous. Playing calming music can help you become more relaxed if you are feeling stressed while driving.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.answerB: Greased.
questions.answerC: Open.
questions.answerD: Removed.
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed, except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can:
questions.answerA: Check for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look for a red light on the front right corner of the converter dolly.
questions.answerC: Pump the air brakes to activate the ABS.
questions.answerD: Assume the vehicle has ABS.
questions.explanation: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is:
questions.answerB: To maximize gas mileage.
questions.answerC: To wake up before the drive.
questions.answerD: To fill up time.
questions.explanation: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is to ensure the safety of yourself and others on the road. Safety inspections before every trip are required by state and federal laws.

questions.question: When checking the engine compartment:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should not be engaged.
questions.answerB: Wheels should be chocked.
questions.answerC: The engine should be running.
questions.answerD: The gearshift should be in first gear.
questions.explanation: Before inspecting the engine compartment, make sure that the parking brakes are on and/or the wheels are chocked. Check the engine compartment before entering the cab and starting the engine.

questions.question: When driving, your mirrors should:
questions.answerA: Not be used, as they are distracting.
questions.answerB: Not be used unless there is traffic.
questions.answerC: Be checked regularly.
questions.answerD: Be checked regularly, but only if it is cloudy.
questions.explanation: It is important for you to be aware of your surroundings at all times. To do this, regularly check your mirrors.

questions.question: Move over laws require:
questions.answerA: Trucks to use the left lane.
questions.answerB: All vehicles to vacate the lane closest to an emergency vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing.
questions.answerC: All vehicles to use the left lane.
questions.answerD: All vehicles to move to the left lane if a flatbed trailer is in the right lane.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle with its lights on is stopped on the side of the road, move over laws require drivers to vacate the lane directly next to the vehicle, if possible. If a driver cannot move over safely, they must slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: What can rust around the wheel nuts indicate?
questions.answerB: That the nuts are wet.
questions.answerC: That the nuts need to be replaced.
questions.answerD: That the nuts are the wrong size.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts can indicate that they are loose. If you observe rust, check the tightness of the nuts.

questions.question: When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that you:
questions.answerB: Make sure there is a large enough gap for your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Expect other drivers to make room for your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Let other drivers wave you into their lane.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more space on the road than other vehicles. When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that there is a large enough gap in traffic for you to safely do so.

questions.question: Hazardous materials may be transported:
questions.answerA: By any driver with a CDL.
questions.answerB: By any driver, as long as the total weight of the hazardous materials are under 50 pounds.
questions.answerC: By any driver in a rural area.
questions.answerD: By a driver with a CDL and HazMat endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: When checking a tank vehicle, it is most important to verify that:
questions.answerB: There is no frost on the windshield.
questions.answerC: The paint is not cracking.
questions.answerD: The tires are new.
questions.explanation: A tank vehicle has a number of items that must be checked during a pre-trip inspection. Refer to the operator's manual for your specific vehicle to ensure that you are checking the vehicle properly. When inspecting any tank vehicle, it is most important to verify that there are no leaks.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Cannot be used on vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Can replace flat mirrors.
questions.answerC: Can be helpful to see a wider area.
questions.answerD: Are illegal to be used in most states.
questions.explanation: Many large vehicles have curved, convex mirrors. Convex mirrors allow drivers to see a wider area than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they really are.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be kept in the vehicle?
questions.answerA: A phone with emergency numbers programmed
questions.answerB: An approved gas mask
questions.answerC: A chemical suit
questions.answerD: Directions for emergency personnel
questions.explanation: A driver transporting chlorine in cargo tanks must keep an approved gas mask and an emergency kit in their vehicle.

questions.question: Parking brakes:
questions.answerB: Should be tested, but only after driving a distance.
questions.answerC: Should be tested before a drive.
questions.answerD: Should be tested on a hill.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should always be checked before driving as a part of your pre-trip inspection. If the parking brakes do not hold, the vehicle is faulty and should be fixed.

questions.question: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and:
questions.answerA: Detach the jaws from around the kingpin.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking lever is in the "emergency" position.
questions.answerC: Remove the safety latch.
questions.answerD: Look into the back of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and look into the back of the fifth wheel. Ensure that the fifth wheel jaws are secured around the shank of the kingpin.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection:
questions.answerA: Should never be completed the same way two times in a row.
questions.answerB: Should always be completed in the same order.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if it is sunny outside.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if the driver thinks the vehicle is in good operating order.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should be completed in the same way before every drive. Consistency will help you learn all of the proper steps and decrease the likelihood that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: To control a surge, brakes should:
questions.answerB: Not be released too quickly after stopping.
questions.answerC: Be used firmly and then released.
questions.answerD: Be used with the parking brake.
questions.explanation: To help reduce the risk of front-to-back surge when stopping a tank vehicle, keep steady pressure applied to the brakes. Do not release them too quickly after coming to a stop.

questions.question: After finishing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerB: Remove the service line valve.
questions.answerC: Leave the emergency line valve open.
questions.answerD: Leave the rear shut-off valves open.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves to listen for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerB: Prevents wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: Makes it easier to turn a large vehicle.
questions.answerD: Assists with the operation of brake lights.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up during hard braking.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.answerB: Stay in the driver's lane.
questions.answerC: Try to race the driver.
questions.answerD: Ignore the driver's gestures.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, the most important thing for you to do is get out of their way. Avoid making eye contact, do not challenge them by increasing your speed, and do not let yourself be provoked by any angry gestures they direct toward you.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The packages should be carried in the cab.
questions.answerC: The packages should be loaded on their side.
questions.answerD: You cannot use bridges.
questions.explanation: Radiation surrounds packages of radioactive materials and passes through to other nearby packages. To address this, the number of radioactive packages that can be loaded together is limited.

questions.question: What should a carrier do if hazardous materials are not properly prepared?
questions.answerB: Accept the shipment under protest
questions.answerC: Accept the shipment, but make a notation on the paperwork
questions.answerD: Refuse the shipment
questions.explanation: It is the responsibility of a carrier to refuse improper shipments of hazardous materials.

questions.question: If a traffic light has been green for a long time:
questions.answerA: It will probably stay green as you approach.
questions.answerB: It is likely broken.
questions.answerC: It is likely that the light will soon change to yellow.
questions.answerD: It is likely the light will skip yellow and change from green to red.
questions.explanation: If you are approaching a traffic light that has been green for a long time, there is a good chance that it will turn yellow before you reach it. Start slowing down and be ready to stop.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when:
questions.answerA: Air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi.
questions.answerB: You are experiencing a trailer jackknife.
questions.answerC: Wheels have regained traction after a skid.
questions.answerD: Air pressure is above 45 psi.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: Why should your mirrors be adjusted to show the road behind you as well as part of your vehicle?
questions.answerA: Having only the road in the mirrors would likely make the driver carsick.
questions.answerB: Having part of the truck in the mirrors serves as a point of reference.
questions.answerC: It is illegal to have only the road in the mirrors.
questions.answerD: The driver should be able to see the reflection of surrounding vehicles on the trailer.
questions.explanation: Part of your vehicle should be visible in your mirrors so that you have a point of reference when judging how close other drivers and objects are to your vehicle.

questions.question: If another driver is following you too closely, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Increase the distance between you and the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.answerD: Avoid relying on tricks to help others pass.
questions.explanation: If you are being followed too closely, you should increase your following distance, avoid making quick moves, and avoid relying on tricks (such as flashing your lights) to help other drivers pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by causing the tailgater to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: When loading a tank, space should be left for outage. What is outage?
questions.answerB: Space for expanding liquids
questions.answerC: Space for additional fuel
questions.answerD: A place for luggage and personal items
questions.explanation: Liquids expand when warmed, so a tank carrying liquid must also contain additional space to accommodate for this expansion. The extra space is known as "outage."

questions.question: If unsure if a road is becoming icy, a driver can:
questions.answerB: Open the window and check the front of the mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Try to look at the road closely.
questions.answerD: Look at a weather forecast.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy, you can check for ice on your vehicle by opening the window and feeling the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: One way to prevent a rollover is to:
questions.answerA: Move cargo to the left side of the rig.
questions.answerB: Keep cargo centered on the rig.
questions.answerC: Move cargo to the right side of the rig.
questions.answerD: Keep cargo as far from the ground as possible.
questions.explanation: A rollover is more likely if cargo is unevenly loaded in a rig. To help prevent a dangerous rollover, it is important to keep a load as centered on the rig as possible.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle, the coolant temperature gauge should:
questions.answerA: Not change from its original position.
questions.answerB: Gradually rise to the normal operating range.
questions.answerC: Jump quickly to the normal operating range.
questions.answerD: Flash until it reaches the normal operating range.
questions.explanation: Keep an eye on the gauges after starting the engine. The coolant temperature gauge should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: Multi-speed axles and auxiliary transmissions are used:
questions.answerA: To make a vehicle run more smoothly.
questions.answerB: To provide extra gears.
questions.answerC: To get improved gas mileage.
questions.answerD: To make a vehicle less noisy.
questions.explanation: On many vehicles, multi-speed rear axles and auxiliary transmissions are used to provide extra gears. They are usually controlled by a selector knob on the gearshift lever.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.answerB: Exchange line
questions.answerC: Surplus line
questions.answerD: Parallel line
questions.explanation: The service line, also called the control line or signal line, carries air to the trailer brakes and is controlled by the foot brake or trailer hand brake.

questions.question: Eating while driving:
questions.answerA: Is a good way to maximize time.
questions.answerB: Is encouraged on long trips.
questions.answerC: Creates a distraction for the driver.
questions.answerD: Is mandatory so cargo is not left unsupervised.
questions.explanation: To reduce the chances of driving distracted, you should avoid eating, drinking, or smoking while driving. Anything that diverts attention from the task of driving is a distraction.

questions.question: Low underneath clearance can cause difficulties when driving:
questions.answerB: On gravel roads.
questions.answerC: Around corners.
questions.answerD: At the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross if you are pulling a trailer with low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: Push in the trailer air supply control to:
questions.answerB: Deactivate the air brakes.
questions.answerC: Sound the horn.
questions.answerD: Supply the trailer with air.
questions.explanation: Push in the trailer air supply control to supply the trailer with air. Pull out the trailer air supply control to turn off the air supply and activate the emergency brakes.

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no more than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement.
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with the heaviest items on top of lighter items.
questions.explanation: Cargo needs to be secured appropriately to prevent it from moving in transit. Cargo should be arranged to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low and well-distributed.

questions.question: What happens when the wheels of a trailer lock up?
questions.answerA: The trailer will usually continue to move in a straight line.
questions.answerB: The trailer will disengage.
questions.answerC: The trailer will likely swing around.
questions.answerD: The trailer will stop.
questions.explanation: A trailer tends to swing around, potentially resulting in a trailer jackknife, if its wheels lock up.

questions.question: A vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) uses a ____ light to warn that the system is not working properly.
questions.answerB: Yellow
questions.answerC: Orange
questions.answerD: White
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunction lamps are usually yellow. Even if the ABS isn't working properly, a driver will still have access to the vehicle's usual braking functions.

questions.question: When an engine is started:
questions.answerA: The brakes should be locked up.
questions.answerB: Warning lights should come on and then quickly turn off.
questions.answerC: The coolant temperature will decrease.
questions.answerD: The hood must be open.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle is started, the warning lights and buzzers should go out after a few seconds. If the warning signals do not turn off, there may be something wrong with the vehicle.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is:
questions.answerB: 8 psi in a minute.
questions.answerC: 6 psi in a minute.
questions.answerD: 4 psi in a minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: Placards should be used:
questions.answerA: Any time a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: If there is open space in the truck.
questions.answerC: If the amount of hazardous materials in the truck exceeds 200 pounds.
questions.answerD: If the hazardous materials create an inhalation hazard.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials. They identify the specific class or classes of materials being carried and warn others of relevant hazards.

questions.question: In a set of triples, the shut-off valves at the rear of the middle trailer should be:
questions.answerB: Closed.
questions.answerC: Polished.
questions.answerD: Open.
questions.explanation: When operating a double or triple, the shut-off valves at the rear of the last trailer should be closed. All other shut-off valves should be open.

questions.question: Over-the-counter medication:
questions.answerA: Poses no safety risks to a driver.
questions.answerB: Is not referenced by any laws regarding driving under the influence.
questions.answerC: Cannot impair a driver.
questions.answerD: Can affect a person’s ability to drive safely.
questions.explanation: Prescription and over-the-counter medications may have side effects that can impair a person's ability to drive safely. It is illegal to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or any other controlled substance, including some over-the-counter medications.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerA: A truck driver is driving too fast.
questions.answerB: The driver of a vehicle in front of a truck is moving to slowly.
questions.answerC: A truck driver is driving too slowly.
questions.answerD: ABS is working effectively.
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen when a vehicle is driven too fast. To reduce the risk of rollover, make sure the weight of cargo is loaded low to the ground, and that you take turns and curves slowly.

questions.question: When uncoupling a dolly, you should:
questions.answerA: Unlock the pintle hook before moving the dolly out from under the rear trailer.
questions.answerB: Move the dolly out from under the rear trailer before unlocking the pintle hook.
questions.answerC: Raise the dolly landing gear.
questions.answerD: Remove the dolly as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: Never unlock the pintle hook with the dolly still under the rear trailer. This could cause the dolly tow bar to fly up, possibly causing serious injury.

questions.question: Why do you need to drain air tanks regularly?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water which must be drained from the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in air pressure
questions.answerD: To remove bad air from the tanks
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: What is a tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve to keep air in the brake system should there be a bad leak
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents the truck from being stolen
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the driver from going too fast
questions.answerD: A valve that prevents the trailer from accidentally being released
questions.explanation: In a combination vehicle with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system in the event of the trailer breaking away or developing a leak.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult to see behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Most trucks do not have the ability to move in reverse.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.answerD: There may be extra weight in the front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Backing up is always dangerous because it is impossible to see everything behind your vehicle. If you must drive in reverse, use a helper, if possible.

questions.question: Which of the following surfaces provides the least amount of traction?
questions.answerB: Ice that is wet
questions.answerC: Wet pavement
questions.answerD: Dry pavement
questions.explanation: Be especially cautious when driving on ice that has begun to melt. Ice that is wet is much more slippery than ice that is dry.

questions.question: What can happen if a parking brake is used in very wet weather when temperatures are below freezing?
