questions.answerB: The brakes may freeze so the vehicle cannot move.
questions.answerC: The brakes may suddenly release by themselves.
questions.answerD: The brakes may explode.
questions.explanation: If you use the parking brakes when the weather is very wet and the temperature is below freezing, the brakes may become frozen, preventing the vehicle from moving.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection includes ____ basic steps.
questions.answerB: Four
questions.answerC: Seven
questions.answerD: Nine
questions.explanation: There are seven basic steps to a pre-trip inspection. These steps include completing an overview of the vehicle; checking the engine compartment; starting the engine and inspecting inside the cab; turning off the engine and checking the lights; a walk-around inspection; checking the signal lights; and starting the engine and checking the brakes.

questions.question: A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause:
questions.answerB: The tractor protection valve to close.
questions.answerC: The rear trailer to detach from the combination.
questions.answerD: The suspension springs to extend.
questions.explanation: The tractor protection valve keeps air in the trailer's braking system should the trailer break away or develop a leak. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the tractor protection valve to open and the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed to get across the tracks as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Roll your window down to listen for a train.
questions.answerC: Rely on traffic control signals.
questions.answerD: Never try to outdrive an approaching train.
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed as you approach a railroad crossing. Remember that you will not necessarily be able to hear a train, and don't assume that signals will warn you of its approach. Never try to outdrive an approaching train at a railroad crossing.

questions.question: A converter dolly that has ABS can be identified:
questions.answerB: By an orange sticker.
questions.answerC: By a yellow lamp on the left side of the dolly.
questions.answerD: By a blue lamp on the left side of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 must have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). A dolly with ABS must be identifiable by a yellow lamp on its left side.

questions.question: Why are roads especially slippery right after it begins to rain?
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerB: Roads are naturally slippery.
questions.answerC: Gravel often gets washed to the middle of the lane.
questions.answerD: Tires are not usually designed to drive in rain.
questions.explanation: In rainy weather, roads are often at their most slippery when the rain first begins to fall. Fresh rainwater mixes with oil and grease on the road to form a slick film. As the rain continues, this mixture will eventually wash away.

questions.question: Before entering a curve, you should:
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Drive on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Downshift.
questions.explanation: Always downshift before entering a curve. Decreasing your speed before entering the curve will allow you to maintain better control over the vehicle throughout the curve.

questions.question: To confirm that a trailer has ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Look under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look under the hood for the ABS sticker.
questions.answerC: Look at the tires.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure if a trailer is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), look under the vehicle for the electronic control unit and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: Which of the following surfaces provides the least amount of traction?
questions.answerB: Ice that is wet
questions.answerC: Wet pavement
questions.answerD: Dry pavement
questions.explanation: Be especially cautious when driving on ice that has begun to melt. Ice that is wet is much more slippery than ice that is dry.

questions.question: Large combination vehicles take the longest amount of time to stop:
questions.answerB: When partially loaded.
questions.answerC: When empty.
questions.answerD: When mostly loaded.
questions.explanation: Large combination vehicles take longer to stop when they are empty than when they are loaded. The decreased weight causes a vehicle's wheels to have decreased traction on the surface of the road.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a distracted person that motorists should be worried about?
questions.answerA: A driver talking to a passenger in their vehicle
questions.answerB: A child on the side of the road
questions.answerC: A construction worker on the side of the road
questions.answerD: A person sitting on a bench waiting for a bus
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are not paying attention to the road. Be wary of road workers, drivers who are engaged in conversation with passengers, and children near the road.

questions.question: Why do you need to drain air tanks regularly?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water which must be drained from the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in air pressure
questions.answerD: To remove bad air from the tanks
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: Passive railroad crossings:
questions.answerB: Are not controlled by any type of traffic control device.
questions.answerC: Have gates that lower when trains are approaching.
questions.answerD: Should never be crossed by a CMV.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings that are not controlled by any type of traffic control device are known as passive crossings. The decision to proceed across tracks at a passive crossing is entirely up to the driver.

questions.question: When backing up to couple a trailer, you should position the tractor:
questions.answerA: At a 90-degree angle in front of the trailer.
questions.answerB: Directly in front of the trailer.
questions.answerC: At a 30-degree angle in front of the trailer.
questions.answerD: At a 60-degree angle in front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When backing up to couple a trailer, you should position the tractor directly in front of the trailer. Trying to couple while backing at an angle could cause the trailer to move and the landing gear to break.

questions.question: While inspecting coupling equipment before a trip, the air lines should not:
questions.answerA: Be connected to the glad hands.
questions.answerB: Have any slack.
questions.answerC: Be secured.
questions.answerD: Be leaking.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the convertor dolly, ensure that all components are present and in proper working condition. Be sure to check the upper and lower fifth wheel, the air lines, and the electric lines. The air lines should be securely attached to the proper glad hands and should not contain any leaks. They should be attached with enough slack to allow easy turning.

questions.question: If unsure if a road is becoming icy, a driver can:
questions.answerB: Open the window and check the front of the mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Try to look at the road closely.
questions.answerD: Look at a weather forecast.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy, you can check for ice on your vehicle by opening the window and feeling the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a driver who might be a hazard?
questions.answerA: A driver operating a vehicle without first scraping ice off the windshield
questions.answerB: The operator of a rental truck
questions.answerC: The driver of a station wagon with items covering the back windows
questions.answerD: A person operating a pick-up truck
questions.explanation: Drivers with blocked vision may pose hazards to others on the road. Examples of such drivers include those who haven't scraped ice off of their windshields; those driving vehicles loaded with large items blocking the windows; and those who are driving rental trucks without being used to the limited rear visibility of a truck.

questions.question: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share:
questions.answerB: Hoses.
questions.answerC: Air lines.
questions.answerD: An air compressor.
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake system share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: Which factor does not have an impact on a person’s blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.answerA: The number of alcoholic drinks consumed
questions.answerB: How quickly the alcoholic drinks were consumed
questions.answerC: The weight of the drinker
questions.answerD: The temperature of the drinks
questions.explanation: The three main factors that determine a person's blood alcohol concentration (BAC) are the amount of alcohol consumed, how quickly the alcohol is consumed, and the person's weight.

questions.question: When traveling down a hill:
questions.answerB: Your speed will decrease.
questions.answerC: Your speed will increase.
questions.answerD: You will slow to a stop.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle is traveling on a downward slope, the force of gravity will cause its speed to increase.

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter the cab due to:
questions.answerB: The wrong type of fuel being used.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.answerD: Under-inflated tires.
questions.explanation: Defects in an exhaust system are very dangerous because they can cause poisonous fumes to enter the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: If you plan to slow down, you can warn drivers behind you by:
questions.answerB: Tapping the brakes a few times and before braking.
questions.answerC: Turning on one set of turn signals.
questions.answerD: Putting your hand out the driver's side window and waving.
questions.explanation: Before slowing down, it is a good idea to flash your brake lights by lightly tapping your brake pedal a few times. This will warn drivers behind you of your plans to slow down.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of fatigue?
questions.answerB: Daydreaming
questions.answerC: Yawning repeatedly
questions.answerD: Drifting from your lane
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued is dangerous. Warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing; repeated yawning or rubbing of the eyes; daydreaming or wandering thoughts; and drifting out of your lane.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.answerB: The nuts are loose.
questions.answerC: The tires should be replaced.
questions.answerD: The nuts are too tight.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.answerB: Have an emergency plan.
questions.answerC: Stay in the left lane.
questions.answerD: Drive above the speed limit.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road to spot potential hazards in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards if they become dangerous.

questions.question: To operate a vehicle that is used to transport hazardous materials, a driver must have:
questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a passenger endorsement.
questions.answerD: A CDL with an air brake endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a commercial driver license with a hazardous materials endorsement before driving a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, even if the vehicle is not transporting hazardous materials at the time of operation.

questions.question: In very hot weather, tires should be checked regularly because:
questions.answerB: Air pressure may increase with the temperature.
questions.answerC: The tread wears down extra quickly.
questions.answerD: The lug nuts may loosen.
questions.explanation: Air expands as it gets warmer, so the air pressure in your tires could reach dangerously high levels while being used in very hot weather. If this happens, stop and let your tires cool. Do not let air out of the tires, as this could result in the pressure dropping to an unsafe level once the tires cool down.

questions.question: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on a package, a ____ placard must be used.
questions.answerB: Explosive
questions.answerC: Radioactive
questions.answerD: Danger
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on a package or its shipping paper, the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate, must be displayed.

questions.question: Outage:
questions.answerA: Should not be considered when loading liquid cargo.
questions.answerB: Is the same for each liquid.
questions.answerC: Should be considered when determining how much liquid to load into a tank.
questions.answerD: Is only a concern in warm weather.
questions.explanation: Because liquids expand when their temperatures increase, some space must be left in a tank to accommodate the expansion. This space is referred to as "outage." The amount of required outage is different for different liquids.

questions.question: Compared to other commercial motor vehicles, combination vehicles need more space on the road because they are longer and they:
questions.answerA: Need more space to turn and stop.
questions.answerB: Drive more slowly.
questions.answerC: Are twice the width.
questions.answerD: Swerve more often.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles need more space on the road than other commercial vehicles because they are longer and need more space to turn and stop. It is especially important to properly manage space when you are operating a combination vehicle.

questions.question: What does the trailer air supply control look like?
questions.answerA: It is a square blue knob.
questions.answerB: It is a triangular yellow knob.
questions.answerC: It is an eight-sided red knob.
questions.answerD: It is a circular orange knob.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles, the trailer air supply control is an eight-sided red knob. It's used to control the tractor protection valve.

questions.question: If unsure if a trailer is equipped with ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Try driving on a slippery surface and see if ABS kicks in.
questions.answerC: Assume it does have ABS.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies built on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). This will be indicated by the presence of a yellow malfunction lamp. You can determine if older trailers have ABS by checking under the trailers for ECU and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: How could you reduce your stress while driving?
questions.answerB: Talk on your cell phone
questions.answerC: Gesture at other drivers
questions.answerD: Listen to calming music
questions.explanation: Being under stress can lead to aggressive driving, which is dangerous. Playing calming music can help you become more relaxed if you are feeling stressed while driving.

questions.question: Roads are most slippery right after it begins to rain because:
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerB: The roads are naturally slippery.
questions.answerC: The gravel gets washed to the middle of the lane.
questions.answerD: Some tires are not designed for rain.
questions.explanation: Roads are particularly slippery when it first begins to rain. The water mixes with oil drippings on the road that have not yet washed away, creating a slippery and dangerous mixture.

questions.question: Avoid needing to make sudden lane changes by:
questions.answerA: Using your horn to encourage other drivers to move out of your lane.
questions.answerB: Only driving slower than the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Watching the road ahead while driving.
questions.answerD: Pulling off the road and waiting when there is high traffic.
questions.explanation: Making a sudden lane change can be dangerous when driving a combination vehicle. Avoid the need to make a sudden lane change by looking down the road for upcoming obstacles that will require you to change lanes.

questions.question: Hydroplaning usually occurs:
questions.answerB: At speeds under 15 mph.
questions.answerC: In areas where water collects on the road.
questions.answerD: During the evening.
questions.explanation: In places where water collects on the road, it is possible for a vehicle to hydroplane. Low tire pressure or worn tire tread makes this more likely to happen. If there is enough water on a road surface, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: A Class 7 hazardous material is:
questions.answerB: Flammable.
questions.answerC: Radioactive.
questions.answerD: Corrosive.
questions.explanation: Radioactive materials are categorized as Class 7 hazardous materials.

questions.question: Carrying liquids in a leaking tank:
questions.answerA: Is acceptable if it is only for a short distance.
questions.answerB: Is illegal.
questions.answerC: Is not dangerous if it is raining.
questions.answerD: Is acceptable if you are running behind schedule.
questions.explanation: When inspecting any style of tank, the most important thing for a driver to check for is leaks. Transporting any type of gas or liquid in a leaking tank is illegal.

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.answerB: One-eighth of a second
questions.answerC: Between three-quarters of a second and one second
questions.answerD: Two seconds
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time of between three-quarters of a second and one second.

questions.question: A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause:
questions.answerB: The tractor protection valve to open.
questions.answerC: The rear trailer to detach from the combination.
questions.answerD: The emergency brakes to activate.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line controls the emergency brakes on a combination vehicle. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: If a traffic light has been green for a long time:
questions.answerA: It will probably stay green as you approach.
questions.answerB: It is likely broken.
questions.answerC: It is likely that the light will soon change to yellow.
questions.answerD: It is likely the light will skip yellow and change from green to red.
questions.explanation: If you are approaching a traffic light that has been green for a long time, there is a good chance that it will turn yellow before you reach it. Start slowing down and be ready to stop.

questions.question: When driving, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Keep your attention focused in front of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Look only to the front and right side of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Look only to the front and sides of your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Look to the front, sides, and rear of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: For safe driving, it is essential that you are aware of what is happening on all sides of your vehicle. In addition to watching the road ahead, you should frequently check your mirrors to monitor the road to the sides and to the rear of your vehicle.

questions.question: When coupling a trailer:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple matching glad hands.
questions.answerB: Any glad hand can be connected to any other glad hand.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand unattached.
questions.answerD: Only one set of glad hands should be connected.
questions.explanation: When coupling, make sure you couple matching glad hands. They are often color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: If there is a collision involving a vehicle transporting Class 1 explosives, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Not warn others of the danger.
questions.answerB: Allow smoking near the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Keep the explosives inside the vehicle until after separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.answerD: Remove the explosives from the vehicle before separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.explanation: If you are driving a vehicle that is transporting Class 1 explosives and it is involved in an accident, you should warn others of the danger, keep bystanders away, and not allow smoking or open fires near the vehicle. Before separating the vehicles involved in the collision, remove all explosives and place them at least 200 feet away from the vehicles and any occupied buildings.

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.answerB: One-eighth of a second
questions.answerC: Between three-quarters of a second and one second
questions.answerD: Two seconds
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time of between three-quarters of a second and one second.

questions.question: With your low beam headlights turned on, you should be able to see about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: 75 feet
questions.answerC: 100 feet
questions.answerD: 250 feet
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights allow you to see about 250 feet ahead of your vehicle. When driving at night, adjust your speed so that you will be able to stop in the distance illuminated by your headlights.

questions.question: The identification number associated with a hazardous material should appear:
questions.answerB: On the vehicle's license plate.
questions.answerC: Directly next to a placard.
questions.answerD: On a bumper sticker on the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It must also appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: A tractor protection valve is:
questions.answerA: A device that keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak.
questions.answerB: A device that prevents theft.
questions.answerC: A device that controls fuel levels.
questions.answerD: A device that allows the battery to recharge efficiently.
questions.explanation: On combination vehicles with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer develop a bad leak or break away from the tractor.

questions.question: Placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: In any manner, as long as they are visible.
questions.answerB: So words and numbers are read from left to right.
questions.answerC: Upside down.
questions.answerD: Within three inches of other markings.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be positioned so any words or numbers can be read from left to right. They must be at least three inches away from any other markings.

questions.question: The service air line is attached to the:
questions.answerB: Supply line.
questions.answerC: Emergency air line.
questions.answerD: Steering wheel.
questions.explanation: The service air line carries air and is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is attached to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied quickly.

questions.question: A CMV should:
questions.answerA: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless the vehicle will be traveling through remote areas.
questions.answerC: Not have a fire extinguisher.
questions.answerD: Have a fire extinguisher and other emergency equipment.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerB: There is no trailer attached to the tractor.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.answerD: The vehicle is on a slight decline.
questions.explanation: If a trailer is attached to a tractor, the adjustment of the vehicle's mirrors can only be checked accurately if the trailer is straight.

questions.question: To ensure you do not interfere with traffic while driving a heavy vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to pass other vehicles while driving uphill.
questions.answerC: Stay in the right lane.
questions.answerD: Ride the brakes while driving downhill.
questions.explanation: If the weight of your vehicle prevents you from matching the speed of surrounding traffic, you should stay in the right lane, if possible.

questions.question: Unbaffled tanks are also referred to as ____ tanks.
questions.answerB: Continuous
questions.answerC: Dynamic
questions.answerD: Standard
questions.explanation: Unbaffled tanks are also often referred to as "smooth bore tanks."

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.answerB: Sunshine.
questions.answerC: Time of day.
questions.answerD: Traffic.
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect your vehicle's stopping distance include driving speed, the vehicle's weight, and the slipperiness of the road surface.

questions.question: When double clutching, if you remain in neutral for too long and can’t get your vehicle into the next gear, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop the vehicle and start over.
questions.answerB: Return to neutral, release the clutch, increase your speed, and try again.
questions.answerC: Skip over your intended gear and move into the next gear.
questions.answerD: Just keep the vehicle in neutral.
questions.explanation: If you stay in neutral for too long while double clutching and have difficulty switching your vehicle into the next gear, don't force it. Return to neutral, release the clutch, increase the engine speed to match road speed, and try again.

questions.question: When passing a bicycle, you must allow at least ____ between your vehicle and the bicycle.
questions.answerB: Two feet
questions.answerC: Four feet
questions.answerD: 15 feet
questions.explanation: When passing a bicycle, you must allow at least four feet of space between the bicycle and your vehicle. If necessary, and if you can do so safely, you are permitted to cross the double yellow centerline so you can maintain the four feet of clearance between your vehicle and the bicycle.

questions.question: After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should:
questions.answerB: Chock the wheels.
questions.answerC: Inspect the fifth wheel.
questions.answerD: Connect the electrical cord.
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should supply air to the trailer.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a distracted person that motorists should be worried about?
questions.answerA: A driver talking to a passenger in their vehicle
questions.answerB: A child on the side of the road
questions.answerC: A construction worker on the side of the road
questions.answerD: A person sitting on a bench waiting for a bus
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are not paying attention to the road. Be wary of road workers, drivers who are engaged in conversation with passengers, and children near the road.

questions.question: When checking the engine compartment:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should not be engaged.
questions.answerB: Wheels should be chocked.
questions.answerC: The engine should be running.
questions.answerD: The gearshift should be in first gear.
questions.explanation: Before inspecting the engine compartment, make sure that the parking brakes are on and/or the wheels are chocked. Check the engine compartment before entering the cab and starting the engine.

questions.question: If you must use the controlled braking method while transporting liquid cargo, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes with about half of your usual force.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes so the wheels lock.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes about halfway, but keep the wheels rolling.
questions.explanation: The controlled braking method for emergency stops involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. Keep steering wheel movements small when braking in this way.

questions.question: When nearing a construction worker who is close to the road, you should:
questions.answerB: Decrease your speed.
questions.answerC: Not drive in any lane.
questions.answerD: Wait until the construction is complete before proceeding.
questions.explanation: When driving through work zones, you should make a particular point of reducing your speed when workers are on or near the road.

questions.question: Charter bus passengers should not be allowed to board until departure time because:
questions.answerA: The cost of the bus starts when the first passenger boards. It saves money to board as late as possible.
questions.answerB: Passengers will be more likely to get on and off the bus multiple times before departing, raising the risk that they will miss the departure entirely.
questions.answerC: Passengers should not be allowed to decide which seats to take until the bus is about to leave.
questions.answerD: Waiting to load helps to prevent theft and vandalism.
questions.explanation: To help prevent theft or vandalism, charter bus drivers should not allow passengers to board the vehicle until departure time.

questions.question: If you are approaching a drawbridge that does not have a signal light or traffic control attendant, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue across the drawbridge with caution.
questions.answerB: Speed up to get across the drawbridge as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Wait for another driver to cross first.
questions.answerD: Stop, look, and make sure the bridge is completely closed before proceeding.
questions.explanation: A bus should always stop at any drawbridge that is not controlled by a signal light or traffic control attendant. Stop at least 50 feet before the draw of the bridge, and make sure that it is completely closed before crossing.

questions.question: If a person is boarding a bus while carrying a container of gasoline, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Place the gasoline container near the back of the bus.
questions.answerB: Keep the gasoline container near the front of the bus.
questions.answerC: Place the gasoline container in the aisle.
questions.answerD: Not allow the gasoline container onto the bus.
questions.explanation: A bus driver should not allow passengers to bring common hazards, such as gasoline or car batteries, onto their bus.

questions.question: Before driving, access panels should be:
questions.answerB: Removed.
questions.answerC: Stored inside the storage compartment.
questions.answerD: Closed.
questions.explanation: You should always inspect the outside of your bus before driving. During this inspection, make sure to close all emergency exits and access panels.

questions.question: A curve's posted design speed is:
questions.answerB: Safe for all vehicles, including buses.
questions.answerC: The minimum speed at which the curve should be driven.
questions.answerD: Not always safe for buses.
questions.explanation: Even under ideal weather conditions, a bus being driven at the posted design speed for a curve could either roll over or slide off the road. For safety, you should reduce your speed before driving a bus around a curve.

questions.question: Carry-on bags should be secured:
questions.answerA: In front of the back door.
questions.answerB: In front of the front door.
questions.answerC: In a location that allows access to all emergency exits.
questions.answerD: On top of the bus.
questions.explanation: Bus passengers must not leave luggage in doorways or aisles. All items should be secured in a way that allows passengers to exit by any door or window in an emergency.

questions.question: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you should:
questions.answerA: Not waste time looking at the handrails and floor lining.
questions.answerB: Make sure the seats are loosely secured.
questions.answerC: Assume all buzzers work properly.
questions.answerD: Make sure emergency exits are easy to use.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure everything is safe and in proper working condition. Make sure emergency exits are properly marked and easy to use.

questions.question: If a bus has a brake and accelerator interlock system, the system should:
questions.answerA: Be turned off in most situations.
questions.answerB: Only be used in inclement weather.
questions.answerC: Never be used in place of the parking brake.
questions.answerD: Operate the rear door.
questions.explanation: Urban transit buses may have a brake and accelerator interlock system, which applies the brakes and holds the throttle in an idle position while the rear door is open. This system should not be used as a substitute for the parking brake.

questions.question: The standee line is:
questions.answerA: A line that passengers must stand behind.
questions.answerB: A line that passengers must stand on.
questions.answerC: A line that should be used as passengers exit the bus.
questions.answerD: A line on the outside of a bus.
questions.explanation: On a bus designed to carry standing passengers, no passengers may stand in front of the rear of the driver's seat. Any such bus must have a line on the floor, or some other marking, that indicates where passengers may not stand. This is called a standee line.

questions.question: When planning to drive a bus that has been parked for a few days:
questions.answerA: The driver should assume the interior is in good working order.
questions.answerB: The driver should call the local police department.
questions.answerC: The driver should do a walkthrough inspection to ensure no damage has occurred since the last trip.
questions.answerD: The driver should ask the passengers to check the interior of the bus.
questions.explanation: People sometimes damage unattended buses. Before driving a bus that has been unattended, you should check the interior to confirm that everything is in proper condition.

questions.question: Buses must never carry:
questions.answerB: Any amount of solid Class 6 poisons.
questions.answerC: Bottled oxygen.
questions.answerD: Emergency hospital supplies.
questions.explanation: Buses may never be used to transport radioactive materials. Division 2.3 poison gas, liquid Class 6 poisons, tear gas, and irritating materials are also not permitted to be carried by bus.

questions.question: On a bus, the driver:
questions.answerA: Does not need to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: Must always wear a seat belt.
questions.answerC: Must wear a seat belt, but only during usual school hours.
questions.answerD: Must wear a seat belt, but only if they have been licensed for less than a year.
questions.explanation: The driver's seat of a bus should be equipped with a seat belt, which must always be used by the driver.

questions.question: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume all emergency exits work properly.
questions.answerB: Loosen every seat.
questions.answerC: Check all signaling devices.
questions.answerD: Not waste time looking at the handrails and floor lining.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure everything is safe and in proper working condition. Make sure all signaling devices, such as bathroom emergency buzzers, work properly.

questions.question: The driver’s seat of a bus should include:
questions.answerA: A pocket for storage on its left side.
questions.answerB: A pocket for storage on its right side.
questions.answerC: A seat belt.
questions.answerD: A cup holder.
questions.explanation: The driver's seat on a bus must be equipped with a seat belt, which the driver should always use.

questions.question: When arriving at a destination, it is best to remind exiting passengers to take their carry-on bags with them:
questions.answerB: After you stop the bus.
questions.answerC: At least five times.
questions.answerD: As they exit the bus.
questions.explanation: Before a bus is brought to a complete stop at its destination, it is best for the driver to remind exiting passengers to take their carry-ons with them.

questions.question: One reason for you to sign a previous driver’s vehicle inspection report is if:
questions.answerA: The previous driver dated their entry.
questions.answerB: Reported defects are certified to have been repaired.
questions.answerC: You plan to drive for longer than one hour or travel farther than 50 miles.
questions.answerD: The report is left on the dashboard.
questions.explanation: You should only sign a previous inspection report if defects were either noted and certified to have been repaired or if repairs were not needed.

questions.question: When stopping at a railroad crossing, opening the forward door:
questions.answerA: Can increase your chances of hearing an approaching train.
questions.answerB: Should never be done.
questions.answerC: Could allow other noises to enter the bus, making it more difficult to hear any approaching trains.
questions.answerD: Will take too long and is discouraged.
questions.explanation: When stopping a bus at a railroad crossing, you should open your forward door if doing so will improve your ability to see or hear an approaching train.

questions.question: If driving a charter bus, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Tell passengers how to operate the TVs, if equipped.
questions.answerB: Not allow passengers to board until the scheduled departure time.
questions.answerC: Allow passengers to board early to get ahead of schedule.
questions.answerD: Tell passengers to fill the back of the bus first.
questions.explanation: To help prevent theft or vandalism, charter bus drivers should not allow passengers to board the vehicle until the scheduled departure time.

questions.question: Before driving a bus that has been left unattended:
questions.answerA: The vehicle should be thoroughly washed.
questions.answerB: Air should be removed from tires.
questions.answerC: The interior should be checked for damage.
questions.answerD: The driver should look for any animals that may have gotten onboard.
questions.explanation: People sometimes damage unattended buses. When inspecting a bus that has been left unattended, you should do a walkthrough to check the interior for damage.

questions.question: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you should:
questions.answerB: Check every handhold.
questions.answerC: Assume all buzzers work properly.
questions.answerD: Remove the emergency exit handles.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure everything is safe and in proper working condition. Take the time to ensure every handhold and railing is securely in place and safe to use.

questions.question: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you should:
questions.answerB: Assume all buzzers work properly.
questions.answerC: Make sure the seats are fastened securely.
questions.answerD: Not waste time looking at the handrails and floor lining.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure that everything is safe and in proper working condition. Ensure that all seats are properly fastened to the bus and safe to be used by riders.

questions.question: When carrying multiple classes of approved hazardous materials on a bus, no more than a combined total of ____ of the materials may be transported at once.
questions.answerB: 50 pounds
questions.answerC: 100 pounds
questions.answerD: 500 pounds
questions.explanation: Buses may carry no more than 500 total pounds of hazardous materials, including no more than 100 pounds of any one class of material.

questions.question: During a bus ride:
questions.answerA: Carry-on baggage may be kept in the aisle.
questions.answerB: Passengers may sit in the aisle.
questions.answerC: Aisles must remain free of obstacles.
questions.answerD: Items may be placed in the aisle if passengers could easily step over them.
questions.explanation: Do not allow riders to leave carry-on baggage in any doorway or aisle. There should be nothing in the aisle that might trip other riders. Secure baggage in a way that prevents damage.

questions.question: Hazardous materials must be marked with all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The material's identification number.
questions.answerC: The appropriate hazard label.
questions.answerD: The phone number of a contact person.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials must be marked with the name of the material, the identification number, and the appropriate hazard label. Do not transport a hazardous material unless you are positive that it is permitted.

questions.question: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you should:
questions.answerB: Check every handhold.
questions.answerC: Assume all buzzers work properly.
questions.answerD: Remove the emergency exit handles.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure everything is safe and in proper working condition. Take the time to ensure every handhold and railing is securely in place and safe to use.

questions.question: At railroad crossings, bus drivers:
questions.answerB: Do not need to stop, but must reduce their speed to 25 mph below the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Do not need to stop, but must open the door to listen for trains.
questions.answerD: Must stop and check for any approaching trains.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing while driving a bus, you must stop between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest track to look and listen for any approaching trains. Only proceed once you are certain that there are no approaching trains. You do not need to stop at streetcar crossings; if a police officer or flagger is directing traffic; if there is a green traffic signal at the crossing; or at crossings marked "exempt" or "abandoned."

questions.question: When approaching a drawbridge that is controlled by a traffic signal, you may proceed:
questions.answerB: Only after coming to a complete stop 50 feet before the bridge.
questions.answerC: Only if other vehicles are also proceeding.
questions.answerD: Only after getting out of your vehicle to check the conditions.
questions.explanation: If approaching a drawbridge that is controlled by a traffic signal displaying a green light, you may slow down and proceed without stopping.

questions.question: On a bus, the driver:
questions.answerA: Is not required to wear a seat belt, but it is recommended.
questions.answerB: Must wear a seat belt.
questions.answerC: Should not wear a seat belt.
questions.answerD: Must wear a seat belt, but only if licensed for less than a year.
questions.explanation: The driver's seat on a bus should be equipped with a seat belt, which should always be used.

questions.question: One reason for you to sign a previous driver’s vehicle inspection report is if:
questions.answerA: The previous driver dated their entry.
questions.answerB: Reported defects are certified to have been repaired.
questions.answerC: You plan to drive for longer than one hour or travel farther than 50 miles.
questions.answerD: The report is left on the dashboard.
questions.explanation: You should only sign a previous inspection report if defects were either noted and certified to have been repaired or if repairs were not needed.

questions.question: Bus accidents most frequently occur:
questions.answerB: On highways.
questions.answerC: On rural roads.
questions.answerD: In parking garages.
questions.explanation: Bus accidents most commonly occur at intersections. Use special caution when driving where you may encounter an increased number of vehicles and pedestrians.

questions.question: When planning to drive a bus that has been parked for a few days:
questions.answerA: The driver should assume the interior is in good working order.
questions.answerB: The driver should call the local police department.
questions.answerC: The driver should do a walkthrough inspection to ensure no damage has occurred since the last trip.
questions.answerD: The driver should ask the passengers to check the interior of the bus.
questions.explanation: People sometimes damage unattended buses. Before driving a bus that has been unattended, you should check the interior to confirm that everything is in proper condition.

questions.question: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume all emergency exits work properly.
questions.answerB: Loosen every seat.
questions.answerC: Check all signaling devices.
questions.answerD: Not waste time looking at the handrails and floor lining.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure everything is safe and in proper working condition. Make sure all signaling devices, such as bathroom emergency buzzers, work properly.

questions.question: Buses should never transport:
questions.answerB: Small arms ammunition.
questions.answerC: Emergency hospital supplies.
questions.answerD: Radioactive materials.
questions.explanation: Buses must never transport labeled radioactive materials in the space occupied by people. Small arms ammunition labeled ORM-D, emergency hospital supplies, and medications are allowed.

questions.question: When stopping at a railroad crossing, opening the forward door:
questions.answerA: Can increase your chances of hearing an approaching train.
questions.answerB: Should never be done.
questions.answerC: Could allow other noises to enter the bus, making it more difficult to hear any approaching trains.
questions.answerD: Will take too long and is discouraged.
questions.explanation: When stopping a bus at a railroad crossing, you should open your forward door if doing so will improve your ability to see or hear an approaching train.

questions.question: Baggage and freight should be stored in a way that:
questions.answerA: Allows passengers to easily see the items.
questions.answerB: Protects riders from injury if items fall or shift.
questions.answerC: Keeps the items in the aisle without shifting.
questions.answerD: Covers windows.
questions.explanation: On a bus, baggage and freight must be stored in a way that allows the driver to move freely and easily; allows passengers to exit via any window or door in the event of an emergency; and protects riders from injury if items fall or shift.

questions.question: Before operating a bus, you should ensure that it is safe by:
questions.answerA: Reviewing the inspection report left by the previous driver.
questions.answerB: Kicking the tires.
questions.answerC: Asking your supervisor if the bus seems safe.
questions.answerD: Asking passengers if they are comfortable.
questions.explanation: A bus must always be inspected before it is driven. The inspection process must include a review of the inspection report made by the previous driver. You should operate the vehicle only if defects listed on the inspection report have been certified as repaired or as not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: A bus driver does not need to stop when approaching:
questions.answerB: A streetcar crossing.
questions.answerC: A railroad crossing.
questions.answerD: A stop sign.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing while driving a bus, you must stop between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest track to look and listen for any approaching trains. Only proceed once you are certain that there are no approaching trains. You do not need to stop at streetcar crossings; if a police officer or flagger is directing traffic; if there is a green traffic signal at the crossing; or at crossings marked "exempt" or "abandoned."

questions.question: On a bus, the driver:
questions.answerA: Does not need to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: Must always wear a seat belt.
questions.answerC: Must wear a seat belt, but only during usual school hours.
questions.answerD: Must wear a seat belt, but only if they have been licensed for less than a year.
questions.explanation: The driver's seat of a bus should be equipped with a seat belt, which must always be used by the driver.

questions.question: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you should:
questions.answerA: Not waste time looking at the handrails and floor lining.
questions.answerB: Make sure the seats are loosely secured.
questions.answerC: Assume all buzzers work properly.
questions.answerD: Make sure emergency exits are easy to use.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure everything is safe and in proper working condition. Make sure emergency exits are properly marked and easy to use.

questions.question: Buses must never carry:
questions.answerB: Soft drinks.
questions.answerC: Medical supplies.
questions.answerD: Tear gas.
questions.explanation: While some kinds of hazardous materials may be carried on a bus under certain conditions, tear gas and irritating materials must never be carried. Small arms ammunition labeled ORM-D and emergency medical supplies are permitted.

questions.question: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share:
questions.answerB: Hoses.
questions.answerC: Air lines.
questions.answerD: An air compressor.
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake system share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: When inspecting your brakes, a slack adjuster should move ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.answerB: More than two inches
questions.answerC: Up to five inches
questions.answerD: No more than one inch
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after setting wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: What kind of force must emergency brakes use?
questions.answerB: Mechanical
questions.answerC: Heavy
questions.answerD: Electrical
questions.explanation: Because air pressure can eventually leak away, the emergency brakes in an air brake system must be held on by mechanical force.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is ____ in one minute.
questions.answerB: 2 psi
questions.answerC: 3 psi
questions.answerD: 4 psi
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Applying the brake pedal causes air pressure to activate an electric switch and:
questions.answerB: Turn on the low pressure warning light.
questions.answerC: Turn on the brake lights.
questions.answerD: Turn off the low pressure warning light.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with air brakes, the brake lights are activated when the brake pedal is pushed and air pressure moves an electric switch. With the application of air pressure, the switch will then turn on the brake lights.

questions.question: Foundation brakes are used:
questions.answerB: Only at the rear wheels.
questions.answerC: Only at the driver’s side wheels.
questions.answerD: At each wheel.
questions.explanation: Foundation brakes are used at each wheel. The most common type is the S-cam drum brake.

questions.question: Brakes may get out of adjustment:
questions.answerB: In colder weather.
questions.answerC: If they are used.
questions.answerD: If they get wet.
questions.explanation: Brakes can get out of adjustment quickly, especially if they are used to the point of overheating. Brake adjustment should be checked frequently.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, once air pressure is lost and the spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: You will be unable to move the vehicle.
questions.answerB: A separate air tank can be used to release the spring brakes for a short period of time.
questions.answerC: You can use the spring brakes to continue driving normally.
questions.answerD: The air tanks will automatically refill to a safe air pressure level.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade, the best way to use your brakes is to:
questions.answerA: Ride the brakes all the way down the hill.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes for a few seconds, then release the brakes for a few seconds. Continue to repeat these steps as you travel down the hill.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes only near the bottom of the downgrade.
questions.answerD: Apply consistent pressure to the brake pedal all the way down the hill.
questions.explanation: On a long or steep downgrade, brakes should only be used to supplement the braking effect of the engine. Apply the brakes just enough to feel a definite slowing down, then release them once you are about 5 mph below your target "safe" speed. Once your vehicle reaches its safe speed again, repeat this process.

questions.question: Before starting down a hill, be sure to:
questions.answerB: Switch into a high gear.
questions.answerC: Sound your horn.
questions.answerD: Switch into a low gear.
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, be sure to switch into a low gear. Gravity will increase your vehicle's speed as you travel downhill.

questions.question: Service brakes should:
questions.answerB: Only be tested by a trained mechanic.
questions.answerC: Be tested before every trip.
questions.explanation: Before driving, you should always verify that your service brakes are in good working order. Testing the brakes before a trip allows you to locate any problems before you need to brake while on the road.

questions.question: When using the controlled braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half of your usual force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes so the wheels lock.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes with minimal pressure.
questions.explanation: The controlled braking method for emergency stops involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. Keep steering wheel movements small when braking in this way.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.answerB: 8 psi in a minute.
questions.answerC: 6 psi in a minute.
questions.answerD: 4 psi in a minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A double combination vehicle should have a leakage rate no higher than 4 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use ____ air brake systems.
questions.answerB: Dual
questions.answerC: Triple
questions.answerD: Quad
questions.explanation: The majority of heavy-duty vehicles are equipped with dual air brake systems.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but keep the wheels rolling.
questions.answerC: Fully apply the brakes, let the wheels lock up, and hold the brake pedal down, keeping the wheels locked until the vehicle stops.
questions.answerD: Apply the emergency brake.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, then the process is repeated.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal should activate:
questions.answerA: When tank pressure falls below 120 psi.
questions.answerB: When tank pressure falls below 60 psi.
questions.answerC: When tank pressure falls below 10 psi.
questions.answerD: When tank pressure falls below 5 psi.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low air pressure warning signal must come on if air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi. This warning signal may come in the form of a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, a leak in one system:
questions.answerA: Always means there are leaks in both systems.
questions.answerB: May not affect the other system.
questions.answerC: Is not something to worry about.
questions.answerD: Will also affect the other system.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: Vehicles with dual air brake systems:
questions.answerA: Maintain full-capacity air pressure in the braking systems even when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerB: Maintain some air pressure in the braking systems when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerC: Must be run to build enough air pressure to brakes to operate properly.
questions.answerD: Do not need time to build air pressure before a trip.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must allow the air compressor time to build up at least 100 psi of air pressure in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: What color is the low air pressure warning light?
questions.answerB: Orange
questions.answerC: Red
questions.answerD: Purple
questions.explanation: A low air pressure warning signal is required in vehicles with air brakes. The warning light is usually red and may be accompanied by a buzzer.

questions.question: How should you test the low pressure warning signal?
questions.answerA: Engage and disable the parking brake.
questions.answerB: Rapidly press and release the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Open the rear shut-off valves.
questions.answerD: Uncouple and recouple all glad hands.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light functions properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: While driving downhill, you should brake until you reach a speed that is ____ below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: 10 mph
questions.answerC: 15 mph
questions.answerD: 20 mph
questions.explanation: While driving downhill, you should hold down the brake pedal until your vehicle reaches a speed 5 mph below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal. Repeat this process.

questions.question: A tank endorsement is:
questions.answerB: Only required when transporting liquids.
questions.answerC: Used when transporting both liquids and gases.
questions.answerD: Optional when transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: In general, a tank endorsement is required to a drive tank vehicle used to transport liquids or gases. This applies to both hazardous and non-hazardous materials.

questions.question: What do anti-lock brakes do?
questions.answerA: Help a driver avoid wheel lockup
questions.answerB: Lock up the front wheels
questions.answerC: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling uphill
questions.answerD: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling downhill
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent the vehicle's wheels from locking up from hard brake application.

questions.question: When you need to stop in an emergency, you should:
questions.answerA: Lock the wheels and skid to a stop.
questions.answerB: Stop in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line.
questions.answerC: Stop in a way that turns your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Expect your vehicle to slow down more quickly than usual.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle traveling in a straight line while still allowing you to turn, if necessary.

questions.question: When you press the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air pressure pushes out the rod and moves the:
questions.answerB: Axle.
questions.answerC: Brake drum.
questions.answerD: Alcohol evaporator.
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: Front wheel braking works:
questions.answerB: Under all conditions.
questions.answerC: Only if the road is dry.
questions.answerD: Under most conditions.
questions.explanation: Front wheel braking is effective under all road conditions. It is unlikely that you will experience a front wheel skid, even on ice.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.answerB: 6 psi in one minute.
questions.answerC: 8 psi in one minute.
questions.answerD: 4 psi in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is:
questions.answerB: 6 psi in one minute.
questions.answerC: 8 psi in one minute.
questions.answerD: 4 psi in one minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: All air tanks must include:
questions.answerB: A lock.
questions.answerC: A trap door.
questions.answerD: A warning sticker.
questions.explanation: Air brake system tanks must contain drain valves. These valves are used to drain accumulated oil and water from the tanks and may be either manually or automatically operated.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Exit the road and park as soon as safely possible.
questions.answerC: Stop where you are and park.
questions.answerD: Put on your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: The service brake system:
questions.answerA: Applies and releases the brakes when you press the brake pedal while driving normally.
questions.answerB: Applies and releases the parking brakes.
questions.answerC: Applies and releases the emergency brake.
questions.answerD: Applies and releases the axle brake.
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system. The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when you use the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share:
questions.answerB: Hoses.
questions.answerC: Air lines.
questions.answerD: An air compressor.
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake system share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.answerB: Dual air brake systems.
questions.answerC: Triple air brake systems.
questions.answerD: Quadruple air brake systems.
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems, in which there are two separate braking systems operated by a single set of controls. Each system operates the brakes on different axles.

questions.question: How is water and compressor oil removed from the bottom of an air storage tank?
questions.answerA: The water and oil are siphoned out of the tank.
questions.answerB: A drain valve is opened to remove the water and oil from the tank.
questions.answerC: The water and oil are removed automatically as the brakes are used.
questions.answerD: A sponge is used to soak up the water and oil.
questions.explanation: Water and compressor oil are removed from air storage tanks through a drain valve. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated tanks must be drained every day to remove this build-up.

questions.question: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Tightens the brake drum onto the axle.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake lining against the wheel.
questions.answerD: Releases air from the air tanks.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: How many air storage tanks are used in an air brake system?
questions.answerB: Four tanks
questions.answerC: Six tanks
questions.answerD: The number varies.
questions.explanation: Air storage tanks are used to hold compressed air. The number and size of air tanks in an air brake system varies among vehicles.

questions.question: If the brake pads rub against the brake drums and create too much heat:
questions.answerB: The brakes will become extra sensitive.
questions.answerC: The brakes may stop working.
questions.answerD: The air compressor will kick on to cool the brakes.
questions.explanation: Brakes heat up with use. If they are overused and become too hot, expansion and chemical changes will make them less effective and eventually cause them to stop working altogether. This is known as "brake fade."

questions.question: In a newer vehicle, you apply the parking brake:
questions.answerA: By using a diamond-shaped yellow knob.
questions.answerB: By using a round red knob.
questions.answerC: By using a square green knob.
questions.answerD: By using a black round knob.
questions.explanation: In a newer vehicle with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the parking brakes and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: The application pressure gauge:
questions.answerA: Shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: Shows the temperature of air being used in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Shows the pressure of the air coming from the compressor.
questions.answerD: Shows the number of times the brakes have been used.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. Not all vehicles with an air brake system have this gauge.

questions.question: What does the air compressor governor do?
questions.answerA: Controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: Controls how quickly air leaves the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: Controls the temperature of the air entering the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Controls the temperature of the air leaving the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: What color is the low air pressure warning light?
questions.answerB: Orange
questions.answerC: Red
questions.answerD: Purple
questions.explanation: A low air pressure warning signal is required in vehicles with air brakes. The warning light is usually red and may be accompanied by a buzzer.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is ____ in one minute.
questions.answerB: 2 psi
questions.answerC: 3 psi
questions.answerD: 4 psi
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: When you press the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air pressure pushes out the rod and moves the:
questions.answerB: Axle.
questions.answerC: Brake drum.
questions.answerD: Alcohol evaporator.
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: When you need to stop in an emergency, you should:
questions.answerA: Lock the wheels and skid to a stop.
questions.answerB: Stop in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line.
questions.answerC: Stop in a way that turns your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Expect your vehicle to slow down more quickly than usual.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle traveling in a straight line while still allowing you to turn, if necessary.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Used while driving.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.answerD: Removed.
questions.explanation: The parking brake in a vehicle with air brakes should be used every time the vehicle is parked.

questions.question: Why do you need to drain air tanks regularly?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water which must be drained from the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in air pressure
questions.answerD: To remove bad air from the tanks
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: When operating a vehicle with a dual brake system, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up before driving to ensure that fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Wait to begin driving until the air compressor builds up a minimum pressure of 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the vehicle starts.
questions.answerD: Pump the pedal about 20 times to build pressure, then begin driving.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air system, allow time for the air compressor to build up a minimum pressure of 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: What kind of force must emergency brakes use?
questions.answerB: Mechanical
questions.answerC: Heavy
questions.answerD: Electrical
questions.explanation: Because air pressure can eventually leak away, the emergency brakes in an air brake system must be held on by mechanical force.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.answerC: By starting the vehicle
questions.answerD: By tapping the accelerator twice
questions.explanation: In vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the brakes, and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tanks.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from the tanks.
questions.answerC: Should never be opened.
questions.answerD: Must remain open while driving.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow water and compressor oil to be removed. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system.

questions.question: What does the trailer air supply control look like?
questions.answerA: It is a square blue knob.
questions.answerB: It is a triangular yellow knob.
questions.answerC: It is an eight-sided red knob.
questions.answerD: It is a circular orange knob.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles, the trailer air supply control is an eight-sided red knob. It's used to control the tractor protection valve.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when:
questions.answerA: Air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi.
questions.answerB: You are experiencing a trailer jackknife.
questions.answerC: Wheels have regained traction after a skid.
questions.answerD: Air pressure is above 45 psi.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: When coupling a trailer:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple matching glad hands.
questions.answerB: Any glad hand can be connected to any other glad hand.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand unattached.
questions.answerD: Only one set of glad hands should be connected.
questions.explanation: When coupling, make sure you couple matching glad hands. They are often color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: When driving a bobtail tractor, you should be aware that:
questions.answerB: Bobtails cannot drive as fast as tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerC: Bobtails are more difficult to stop than tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerD: Bobtails are illegal in most states.
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to bring the bobtail to a complete stop than it would a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: When a combination vehicle goes around a corner:
questions.answerA: The turn should be made as tightly as possible.
questions.answerB: The front and rear wheels move in different paths.
questions.answerC: The rear wheels should run over the curb.
questions.answerD: It is acceptable for street signs to be knocked over if they are too close to the road.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is called off-tracking. This effect is especially pronounced on vehicles with trailers.

questions.question: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be:
questions.answerA: Slightly higher than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerB: Level with the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerC: Slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerD: Next to the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be correct. It should be slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.

questions.question: If a trailer is too high:
questions.answerA: It will not make a difference when coupling.
questions.answerB: It may not couple correctly.
questions.answerC: Coupling will be more secure.
questions.answerD: Coupling will be easier.
questions.explanation: Before coupling together a tractor and a trailer, you should make sure the trailer is at the proper height. If the trailer is too low, the trailer nose may be damaged. If the trailer is too high, it may not be able to couple correctly.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerA: A truck driver is driving too fast.
questions.answerB: The driver of a vehicle in front of a truck is moving to slowly.
questions.answerC: A truck driver is driving too slowly.
questions.answerD: ABS is working effectively.
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen when a vehicle is driven too fast. To reduce the risk of rollover, make sure the weight of cargo is loaded low to the ground, and that you take turns and curves slowly.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.answerD: Should not be driven.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.question: Air pressure in the ____ air line is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake.
questions.answerB: Service
questions.answerC: Rear
questions.answerD: Auxiliary
